dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The man who said "I'd rather be lucky than good" saw deeply into life. People are afraid to face how great a part of life is dependent on luck. It's scary to think so much is out of one’s control -- there are moments in a match when the batl hits the top of the net, and for a split second it can either go forward...or fall back. With a little luck, it goes forward...and you win. Or maybe it doesn't...and you lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris walks along a fence. He carries a letter and @ familiarizes himself with the tennis club manager's nam

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (mumbles } Mr. Townsend. He glances around at club members playing tennis.

dialogues.speaker: INT, TENNIS CLUB TOWNSEND'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Townsend enters through the doorway, clutching Chris' res

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSEND
dialogues.text: (to Chris) Just this way. Chris follows behind as Townsend gestures, reading off Ch previous job positions.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSEND
dialogues.text: So...the Beach Club Marbella, tennis instructor...Stanford House, @ Forte Village. Sardina...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I had a good deal of experience.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSEND
dialogues.text: Yeah, so I see. And I've heard very good things. You don't miss playing professionally?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (sighs) Thank God every day I don't have to do it. I hate the whole tennis tour thing. Constant travelling and I was never going to be Rusedski or Agassi. You have to really want it. Not that I have their talent.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSEND
dialogues.text: Well, your credentials and references are excellent. And you want to live in London?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Very much. Very much.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSEND
dialogues.text: (softly) (beat) We have a very exclusive membership here. (beat) You can begin this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you very much, cUuUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing.

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE AGENT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Er, that's your sofa... cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE AGENT
dialogues.text: «+-which also doubles up as a bed. Which is great, you know, ‘cause you can be watching some telly, you ain't got the hassle of having to go to a bedroom. You can just open it up, get your kip... Er, kitchen just through there... Chris looks through the doorway into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE AGENT
dialogues.text: All your amenities -- fixtures, fittings, washer/dryer, all that stuff. Lovely view, not overlooked. So, er, it's all good.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: This is two hundred and twenty-five a week?

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE AGENT
dialogues.text: Well, it's London, mate. Bang, mate. You know, if you don't like it, move to Leeds. D'you know what I mean? (beat) .-.You got a wok? It's one of those oriental sort of conical pans?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No, no, no...

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE AGENT
dialogues.text: The geezer who was in here before, he left one in there. You're welcome to it. I'1l throw that in.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE AGENT
dialogues.text: {nods) That's a good choice. cur TO:

dialogues.text: Chris is seated at a table, eating. He looks at a magazin reaches for a drink. cUuT TO:

dialogues.text: A montage of male and female club members play tennis wit Chris, who instructs.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: «..Very good... cur TO:

dialogues.text: Chris is on the sofabed, reading Dostoyevsky's "Crime and Punishment". He sets it down and picks up another book: “ Cambridge Companion to Dostoevskii".

dialogues.text: Townsend walks with Tom Hewett and introduces him to Chri

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSEND
dialogues.text: Chris Wilton...this is Tom Hewett. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Very nice to meet you. How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Good morning, Tom. Pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSEND
dialogues.text: I think Chris would be the perfect - instructor for you and he's very . patient. Great at analyzing a player's faults.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exhales ) I'm so out of practice. I mean, I haven't played since wniversity and I loved it but, um, I haven't picked up a racket in bloody ages, SO...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Don't worry, it comes back. What you can’t do is rush in, he discouraged.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSEND
dialogues.text: (stepping away) Well, good luck.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. @ Townsend shakes Tom's hand, then turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (gestures to the other side of the court) Over here.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Brilliant. Cur TO:

dialogues.text: Tom and Chris sit at a table.

dialogues.speaker: . TOM
dialogues.text: Okay, so who was better, or @ tougher? Henman or Aghassi?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: They were both great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, but I mean you, you held your own more than admirably.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: For a while. Tom lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: CERIS
dialogues.text: But as the game goes on you see how really good they are. A waitress places the bill onto their table.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I'll get this.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no,

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No, please Tom. I insist, I insist.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no, na, no. Get your dirty great forehand off. Tom looks down at the bill.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Thank you. I'll get the next one.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: So, do you need a lift after this?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Actually, I'm looking for a music store. I want to buy some CD's.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Music around here?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Mmm—hmm.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: . I think there's one on the Fulham Road.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: And they'll have a decent opera section?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opera? You like opera, really?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, I love opera.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Popa gives loads to the Royal in Covent Garden. I know this is gonna sound a bit weird but...would you like to go to the opera tomorrow night?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: To the opera?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah. We've got a box and someone's hot coming. It's La bloody Traviata.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: My God. I'd love to. Are you sure it's not an imposition? Can I at least pay for my seat?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It's not an imposition, it'd be an absolute pleasure. I just like the fact that we both share a love for opera. Brilliant. curT TO:

dialogues.text: Establishing. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: . So?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: So I said to David and Melissa that we would see them...  Tom enters, followed by Chris.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Evening all.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to Eleaor) Hello, mum. He leans in and kisses her on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Hello, sweetie. Very nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: (to Eleanor) Where are you going to see them?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Oh, this is, this is Chris, Chris, this is my father, Alec...

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Ah... Chris and Alec shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hello, good to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: I hear you're an incredible tennis player. I played once and then I gave up, and then I went back, then I gave up, then I went back...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Oh rubbish. Anyway...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I'm sure Tom exaggerated my game.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: « I just got bored.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (to Eleanor) Hello. Good evening. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: And this is my sister... Tom kisses Chloe's head.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: There’s a chair somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: +--Chloe, Chris and Chloe shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Hello. Hi, I'm Chloe. Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hello, Chloe. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (referring to the seats) There's two more there... cur To:

dialogues.text: Tom, Chris, Alec, Chloe, and Eleanor watch the opera. Chl glances over at Chris, sitting nearby. curt To: INT. TOM'S OFFICE -—~ DAY Tom is seated at a cluttered desk, clutching a cordless telephone receiver and toying with a cigarette lighter.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yeah, well, the olds say thank you very much for the er, lovely flowers. They said it was very thoughtful and totally unnecessary. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 TOM (cont'd) But, er, off the record well done, A plus, ‘cause they love that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris talks to Tom on his mobile phone,

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: {into phone) Oh, they're lovely people. And your sister's very bright. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: {into phone) Frighteningly so at times...But er, anyway, she thought you were terrific and she wanted to invite you to cur house with the parents on Sunday. Er, ‘cause they're having a party, there’1ll be some good people. And, er, I'll play you some great music because dad's got an epic collection... cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and Tom play tennis. Chloe watches from afar, clutc a tennis racket.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Chlo-Chlo, do you wanna have a knock with Chris for a bit? It's just that it's five o'clock somewhere darling, and I've got some serious cocktail'’s to start making. : (to Chris) Irish ~- Have you ever had a Cuba Libre or a Caipirinha?  11

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: No, it'd be really boring for Chris to play with me on my own.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Well it's really boring for him to play with me but he’s a good sport. And anyway...you've got better legs than I've got. Chop-chop.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Don't be silly. I teach people who have never held a racket.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I'm so bad. Tom turns, exits.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: That's how you get better. Playing with a stronger player. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Okay. They begin playing.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. HEDLEY ESTATE SWIMMING POOL TERRACE --— DAY Chloe and Chris walk along the terrace,

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Was I dreadful?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Not at all. You have a very unique style,

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's called clumsey. How did you get to be so good, anyway? Tom says you. played some of the greats.

dialogues.speaker: . CHRIS
dialogues.text: For me, it was a way out of a poor existence. Caught the eye of a good coach. I don't know. It all came so easy at first.  12

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Do you enjoy teaching?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Not really. I mean, it’s okay for now but I'd cut my throat if I thought I had to do it forever. I'd like to do something with my life. You know, special. I'd like to make a contribution.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: So you're a poor boy from Ireland come to London.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I love it. It’s so exciting and alive. I've never seen so much art or theatre. Not that I've taken much advantage of it yet.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Well, look, if you'd like someone to show you around...I grew up in Belgravia, I'd be happy to take you to all the good places.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: That'd be great. On one condition: I buy the tickets.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Oh dear, is that going to be an issue?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it is, I'm very old fashioned. But actually I did read something about the exhibition in the Saatchi Gallery.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: That's perfect. It'd be my pleasure to take you.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You're very kind to offer this. Can I at least give you some free tennis lessons?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Okay, it's a deal. How about Wednesday for the Saatchi?  13

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I can do that.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Shall we meet for lunch first?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Tt's a date. I'd better get ready. Your guests will be arriving soon.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, of course. Go.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: A sweaty tennis player's hardly what they expect. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guests mill about on the lawn. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris enters, brushing off his suit jacket. He passes thr a doorway and into the library, then down another corrido and approaches a ping pong table.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA, (0.5.)
dialogues.text: So -~ who's my next victim? You?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I haven't played table tennis in quite a while.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: Would you like to play for a thousand pounds a game?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What did I walk into? They play. Chris smashes the ping pong ball across the ta He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: What did I walk into?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like this. May I?

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You have to lean in...and hit through the ball.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: I was doing just fine until you showed up.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Ah, the story of my life. So tell me...what's a beautiful young American ping-pong player doing mingling amongst the British upper class?

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: Did anyone ever tell you you play a very aggressive game?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Did anyone ever tell you you've very sensual lips? NOLA. Extremely aggressive.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I'm naturally competitive. Is it off putting?

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: I'll have to think about that for a while.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (0.5.)
dialogues.text: Bh, there you are. I wanted to introduce you to Chris Wilton... Tom enters, clutching a drink.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: : Chris Wilton this is Nola Rice. My fiancee.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: Aha ~~ so you're the tennis pro, 14  15

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: .--Hello, darling. He kisses her on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: ...My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: He was trying to have his way with me over the table,

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Oh really? Yeah, well, you'd better watch out for this one. He's made a living out of hustling.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: I'll be ready for you next time. She turns, kisses Tom.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: I'll see you outside.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (sighs) She's quite something, isn't she.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: How long have you been together?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Oh, six months...Jesus, yeah, six months! She came over to study acting and I met her at a party that I'd crashed and she'd crashed and one thing led to another. Obviously it's taken mother quite a long time to get used to the idea that I'm serious but to be honest with you, mother’s always had this - funny little agenda for me which doesn’t really involve marrying a struggling actress. Especially an American one. But I am crazy about her. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 TOM (cont'd) Anyway, I think we should all go to dinner next week. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I'd love to.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Excellent. Now, Irish, how about a little drop of Scottish before supper?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Why not.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Lead on. Quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chloe and Chris walk together.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. THAMES EMBANKMENT --— DAY Chloe and Chris, together. cuUT TO: EXT. ST. JAMES PARK -— DAY Chloe and Chris glance at Buckingham Palace, the Queen's Guards in the background. cur To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and Chloe are seated in a near empty auditorium.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: . These afternoons have been great. I'm so glad your schedule allows you so much time off.  17

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes, it's fun. Although it wouldn't hurt to have a few more pupils.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Do you need money?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: God, no. I'm fine. It's very sweet of you to ask but I don't.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I'm only asking because I care about you. They kiss passionately.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Shall we go to your place or mine?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I don't think mine's quite what you're used to.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Shut up. I think yours'll be just great. They kiss again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chloe and Chris make love on Chris's sofabed. cur To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor and Chloe walk together.  18

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You've been seeing a lot of Chris Wilton lately, I understand.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Yeah. He's very nice,

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I liked him. I just don't understand what he's aiming for.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: He certainly doesn't want to be a tennis pro for the rest of his life. Alec, seated nearby, overhears.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Well, I find him very likeable. He's found his way up the only way open to him and he's not trivial. I had a very interesting conversation with him the other day about Dostoyevsky.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Can't we do something for him? A place in one of your companies or something?

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Has he expressed a desire?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: No, but he’s open, you know, about his future.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: He really wants to make something of his life.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Chloe -- be careful. Tom’s involved . with a woman I have reservations about. Don't rush off.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Tom's happy with Nola. You're prejudiced cause she's American.  19

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: She's spoiled and temperamental.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: She's an actress, they're emotional.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: She’s deluding herself and she's moody. She’s not right for Tom.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Who are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Nola.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Ooh. coT TO: e INT. LOCANDA LOCATELLI -~ NIGHT Chloe enters a restaurant and spots Chris seated at the b She walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Have you been waiting ages?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hello. Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Traffic was awful. The others'1ll be here in a minute. They're probably stuck in it somewhere. (to waiter) Can I have a champagne cocktail, please?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: One of your father’s associates spoke to me today about the possibility of a job. Did you say anything?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: e Look, I just told papa to keep his eyes open if anything juicy opened up. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 CHLOE (cont'd) So you could have first option...if you wanted it. You're not cross are you?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: God, no. It's extremely thoughtful of you. The waiter brings Chloe's drink.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I'm gonna have to think about it. I've never really seen myself in the business world.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Mhh-hmm. So, what do you see for yourself, you know, in the future?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I don't know really. I mean, I'm sure its a great opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I'm think it is. Papa said it's a chance to learn the business. And if things go well, he'll see to it, you know...that you move up quickly or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I've always felt so-so about office work.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: It's not exactly office work, Think of it more as a stepping stone.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: To a bigger job, more responsibility, greater earning potential, I don't know. You've always said how much you admire Papa's accomplishments.  They kiss. 21

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Of course. I mean -- it's strange but coming where I come from, I've always admired men like your father. Wealthy but not stuffy. Enjoying his fortune. Having a grand time, supporting the arts.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Well, he'd really like to open some doors for you, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: He's a very generous man.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: He respects how you've pulled yourself up against the odds... You don't seem very enthusiastic.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I hope my hesitation isn't upsetting.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: No, no, not at all. It’s just that, you know, you've always talked about making a contribution and...I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I will. I promise. Chloe sees Tom and Nola enter the restaurant. She waves.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Oh good.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hi, guys. Chloe and Nola begin chattering. cur TO:  SAME -—- A FEW MINUTES LATER 22 Chris pulls the chair out for Chloe as she seats herself table. Tom nods,

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: «+.Don'’t worry, the traffic was awful.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It's my fault. I dragged Nola to the classic car show at ExCel.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It was unbelievable. I swear my trousers have barely dried.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Oh God. Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Well you love your cars, though, don't you Chris?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I think the old ones are beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I like the old ones. But Tom likes .all those new ones with the gadgets and... raises his eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: I want an Aston Martin.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I drive an Aston Martin.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Really?  23

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, I used to work for a man and I used to wash his cars for him. He was very, very particular about... Chloe turns and takes a menu from the waiter.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I can't help it. You drive me crazy.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: You're gonna be late for work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. Come on. They enter the Nola's apartment building together. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: . NOLA
dialogues.text: Oh, Mrs. Eastby, hello.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. EASTBY
dialogues.text: Oh, hello.  67

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: Hey, did you get that, uh, pest control...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. EASTBY
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes. Yes. The traps work better with a little peanut butter. It's much better than cheese despite the popular notion that cheese is best.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. EASTBY
dialogues.text: Hello, hello.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Good to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: See you later.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. EASTBY
dialogues.text: Bye-bye.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: Bye. Nola and Chris enter Nola’s flat. cur TO:

dialogues.text: Chris tosses Nola’s handbag to the floor and pulls off hi jacket. Nola pushes the door closed, removes Chris‘ tie, blindfolds him with it as she unbuttons his shirt. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heather and Tom are seated with Chris and Chloe.  68

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: But I think that Bruton Street would be perfect for the gallery because it's just right in the thick of things and...it'1ll just be a natural success I think, because you're great at picking out paintings and bric-a~brac.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Knowing my luck, I'1l get pregnant the minute it opens.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you can manage both. I mean, Heths didn't have a problem giving up Adair when we first had Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Remember, we did have a lot of help though.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: But the nanny left us. She got a part in a movie.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: No?_

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Oh, actually, you know, you know who we bumped into the other day? Obviously you know but...

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: »-.Nola.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Well, I told you, we saw her...when was it? Ages ago now.  69

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Mmm.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well I think she's now working in a boutique on Ledbury Road. I think it's Paul or Joe's or something.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Mmm.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: But she’s just such an odd girl. I mean she still looks great. Sorry but it's true. Er -- but something's just...changed in her face. I mean I, we barely spoke.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Tom said she looked a bit hard.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, she's always, you know, been a lady of the sauce so to speak. And I think it kind of runs in the family, but...I don’t know. I mean she’s still got that "come hither” look.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Is she going out with anyone?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Strangely, I forgot to ask. Burt and Phoebe approach.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hello, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hello, fella.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We just popped in for a bit of, you know, local tagliatelle.  70

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: My goodness, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Good to see you. What a lovely family gathering.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Well, you should have told us you'd made a, a, we'd have made a sextet...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: 7e+a sextet. We could have had one of those.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Are you guys going to Hedley next month?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (to Heather) »--Yeah, we're gonna try. Aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're gonna try, yeah. I know Tom's dying to get away.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hey, I was yelling at you the other day. You didn't, you didn't hear me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Yeah, you were hailing a cab on Melcombe Street about, er, what, five o'clock? I'd have given you a lift.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I was?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Where's Melcombe Street?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No, not me.  71

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Yes -- I mean it certainly looked like you.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Where is Melcombe Street?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No, I'm afraid you‘re mistaken. But people are always taking me for other people. So...

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: I'd have sworn it was you.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Well, it certainly wouldn't be Chris hailing a cab. He's completely dependant on our driver. Very annoying.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Quite right.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: You should check for early Alzheimer's, you're forgetting. I'm sure I'm right.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No, you are mistaken. But...thank you for thinking of me.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I think the only thing that comes out of this conversation is that you're both nuts.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you're an authority on that.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Or drunk.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Look, we'd better be going. Look, call me.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I will do.  72

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Enjoy your supper.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Bye. See you.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Thanks. Burt and Phoebe step away.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to Heather/Chloe/Chris) «Nuts. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris enters.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Ingrid... Samantha, what do we have for this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Er, just the Sarazin people at two.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Can we push it an hour? I should be back in time but if I'm not, please make them comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Rod, standing at the reception desk, overhears their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: Chris -- where are you off to?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I‘m sorry, Rod. I've got an appointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have Sarazin and Company this afternoon.  73

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I should be back in time but if I'm not, please start without me.

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: It's okay. It’s important. Trust me. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: EXT, STREET
dialogues.text: Nola and Chris walk together.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: It's ridiculous to go back to my place. Once we get there you'll have less than an hour.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Look, it's not that I'm miserable with Chloe, it's just...

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: I don't wanna talk about Chloe any more.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Listen, it's just I'm bored! I mean, she's very nice but...

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: Chris!

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Are you in a bad mood?

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: Yes, I am in a bad mood. cur TOs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris and Nola sit at the bar.  74

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: I just blew another audition. I'm so sick of the acting thing, it's just not working out.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: It's a hard field. You have to keep plugging at it.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: I'm sick of plugging. Tom's mother was right. It just gets to a point. Or should I say your mother-in-law?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hey, look -- let's not go into one of those, okay?

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: I don't know what I'm doing with you. You're never gonna leave Chloe.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Maybe I will.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: Don't say that unless you mean it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Chloe's just so desperate to get pregnant. I mean, it's mechanical. T don't know what I'd do if I couldn't see you. Really, I mean it.. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, Chloe and family are seated around a Christmas tree.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Merry bloody Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: - Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: How many cigarettes are you gonna smoke today?  75

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: A million, at least.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Please don't start smoking.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Well, it is Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It's such a pity.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Come on, just a little one.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Tf you think you're going to be living forever, you're not... Elsewhere, Chris talks softly into his mobile phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (to Nola) I wanted to wish you a Merry Christmas. I’ve been thinking about you...I may be able to get away tomorrow for an hour or so...Okay. See you then. Bye-bye.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: There you are, Chris... Alec enters from the stairway.

dialogues.speaker: . ALEC
dialogues.text: Chloe tells me you've sustained some personal loss in the market over the past few months...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I've been a little bit careless, not concentrating. And of course I thought I made good decisions but...

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Well, who could have predicted. Look I don't want you and Chloe ta worry. You'll always have a safety net.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You're too generous, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Oh, no, you've made Chloe happy and that means a great deal to Eleanor and me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris rubs baby oil onto Nola’s back. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chloe and others are seated around a table. Burt stands behind Phoebe, toying with her hair. Chris and Tom clutch cups of tea.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Well I think it's going to be an amazing holiday. Don't you, Chris?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Oh, we have a choice of sleeping on the boat or in the different hotels.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Ah,.boat. Every time.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Boat.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Good. I say the boat.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Do you know he's never been to the Greek Islands?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: - What?

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: No?  77

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: No, he’s never been.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: You'll love it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No. I have been to Athens but I hear the Islands are paradise.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Oh, that reminds me, we have to go to Sardinia to pop in on Brook and Dougie Winston.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Oh good.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Oh God.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: No, no, the house is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No, Brook's fine, Dougie's a nightmare, but...

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Sounds so romantic, doesn't it? Mykonos and Crete.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: I'm so anxious to see all the beautiful old temples and theaters.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Ok God.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Oh, I'l] do that with you.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: You know, I bought Chris an ancient Greek fertility charm. Do you remember?  He lowers 78

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I'll never forget.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I sent off for that fertility thing. He had to put it under his pillow for two months. And absolutely nothing happened, of course. Poor thing. I'd just subjected him to the torture.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: They think he's firing blanks.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up!

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (into mobile phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: NOLA, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: I miss you.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I can't get away right now.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Well you have to. When can you get here?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. No, Monday. Look...it's a three day weekend. Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, I need to see you.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I'il see what I can do. I'11 call you right back. the phone and ends the call.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (continuing) ++I would love to meet Barbra Streisand.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Oh, she's meant to be really lovely. She's with that other American fella.  79

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (re: phone call) Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm such an idiot. I forgot to sign some papers. I have to drive into town.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Oh, you can't go. It's a bank holiday weekend. The traffic'll be terrible. I mean, we've all got plans.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I don't mean today.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Well surely it can wait a couple of days.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm sure it can...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. HEDLEY ESTATE DINING ROOM —- EVENING Tom, Heather, Eleanor, Alec, Chris, and Chloe are seated around a dining table.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: I think tomorrow we should go for a morning ride.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: I've some lovely new horses.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Do you remember when Chris came here first and he had some serious qualms about riding?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Well, this morning he was talking about buying a horse of his own.  80

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Yeah. The housekeeper leans in to Chris.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: Telephone call, sir. She said it was important.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Excuse me,

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to Alec} Tomorrow morning then?

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Do you want to come?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: That bloody phone has not stopped ringing all weekend!

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: It’s so irritating. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris follows the housekeeper to the phone. He picks up t receiver.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: NOLA, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: I tried to call your mobile but it’s off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you mad calling me here?

dialogues.speaker: NOLA, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: When, when are you coming over?  81

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I'm trying to make it for tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: I can’t wait till tomorrow. I'm going crazy.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: What the hell’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: NOLA, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: I'm pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I'll...talk to you tomorrow. He slowly lowers the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ..eIt was lack of enough vegetables or something.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I wonder if that's why they took lemons and oranges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they only had biscuits. Well, that's where Rose's Lime Cordial originated... Chris sits down beside Chloe.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Who keeps calling?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIST
dialogues.text: It was Samantha, my secretary. I'm afraid I won't be able to go riding tomorrow. I can't help it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I thought Samantha said she was going to her parents this weekend?  82

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I know it, it's all my fault. Poor girl. It's no big deal. I'11 pop back into town. The whole thing'1l take a few hours and it'll be off my mind. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: That's a shame.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: It's really sad.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Well, it is a pity because I think it's unfair for Samantha too, frankly.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Well, it’s unfortunate, but you know Chris has a lot of responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Well, anyway, less said... Let's not worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Slave driver. cuT TO: INT. NOLA'S FLAT --— LATER Chris paces.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: How the hell did you get pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: I told you that weekend last month that we needed to be careful and I didn’t have protection, but you * couldn't wait.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What unbelievably bad luck, Christ, I can't get my wife pregnant no matter how hard I try. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 83 CHRIS (cont'd) And the minute you're unprotected, I knock you up.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: It's 'cause you love me and you don't love her.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Is that your interpretation?

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: It's a child conceived out of genuine passion not as part of some fertility project.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Well I'll go with you and we'll get it sorted.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: I'm not doing that again.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Again? What's that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: It's the third time. I did it once when I was younger and then I did it for Tom. I didn't want to but he insisted.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Nola, I really can't see any other way.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: Why can't I just have it?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: And then what? NOLA. And we'll raise it together.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: That’s obviously not possible.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: Why? You hate your job, you hate your life. I mean it seems like a blessing. It's a sign.  84

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Look, Nola. I have to go. I'm juggling six things at the same time just to make this trip to the city look legit. I'l1 talk to you on Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: NOLA
dialogues.text: Chris -- you must... I expect you to do the right thing, okay? I'm not walking away from this. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Is anything the matter? You seemed very gloomy all weekend?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Us.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. There is.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: What? If you're still taking a hammering financially in the market, you know it’s not a problen.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I can't keep leaning cn your father, Chloe.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: * Papa gets more pleasure cut of helping his family than all the possessions he owns. You know that. (beat) What is it? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85 CHLOE (cont'd) Is it something to do with those phone calls you kept getting? ‘Cause you acted really strangely after each of them. (beat) Are you having an affair?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Am I having an affair?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's what I asked.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (beat) No.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: You are.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Of course I'm not. Don't be silly.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Do you not love me any more?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Oh course I love you.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Well what's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I just feel like I'm letting you down.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: You're not. Is it because I'm not getting pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I just...feel so guilty. So terribly guilty.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Listen, Chris, we've both been to the doctor. We're both perfectly healthy. I can conceive and you're perfectly capable of making a woman pregnant. Is it me? Have I been horribly pushy and obnoxious on the subject? Look, I just want a baby. I want to have our baby. We haven't been lucky yet, that's all.  86

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Oh, Chloe. Chris kisses her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Let's get off the subject. Having a child should be something that makes us both happy and excited, not a cause of all this tension and anxiety and... They embrace. cur TO: EXT. PARK -—— DAY Chris and Henry are seated on a park bench.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I had to talk to somebody. I'm really suffering.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Whatever you tell me -- goes no further.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I'm contemplating leaving my wife for another woman.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: But when the time came to tell her..-I couldn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, it's not the easiest thing in the world to do, is it?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: It's crazy. I can see no real future with this other woman, and I . have a very comfortable life with my wife.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but if you don't love her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not saying I don't love her. Just not in the way I feel about this woman.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Come on, he is a handsome boy. Look at that face.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Lorna sent some lovely flowers.  130

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah, he’s gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Right, here we are. Alec enters with a bottle of champagne and glasses on a t

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I'll pass them round, shall I?

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmm. Please do.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Chloe, darling, have one.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: With parents like Chloe and Chris, this child will be great with anything he sets his mind to. Eleanor hands Tom a glass of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Thank you, mummy. Do you know what, I don't care if he’s great. I just hope that he’s lucky.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Oh, Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What a lovely thought.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Mummy, are you sure I'm allowed champagne?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. Just a tiny weeny bit...

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Yes, of course you are.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You haven't had any for months, Chloe. I'd get it down you now while you can.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Isn't he handsome? My God, he's handsome.  BLACK. 131

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Bet you any money the next one's a girl.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Mmm.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: He's got the most adorable cheeks...

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: .«--dust so extraordinarily handsome. I wonder what he's thinking.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Well, you know, they said he was a thinker. The nurses...

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Deep thoughts. Deep thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Here we are. (toasting) To Terrence.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: And all that sail on him.
